thread.title: A look around Oroville Dam as 200,000 people are evacuated
thread.title_full: A look around Oroville Dam as 200,000 people are evacuated

title: A look around Oroville Dam as 200,000 people are evacuated

organizations.name: european pressphoto agency none chris mitchell
european pressphoto agency none oroville lake

text: A look around Oroville Dam as 200,000 people are evacuated Rich Gray, of the Placer County Sheriff Dept., monitors the Oroville Dam's main spillway from a lookout point on Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Crews working around the clock atop the crippled Oroville Dam have made progress repairing the damaged spillway, state officials said. Post to Facebook A look around Oroville Dam as 200,000 people are evacuated Rich Gray, of the Placer County Sheriff Dept., monitors the Oroville Dam's main spillway from a lookout point on Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Crews working around the clock atop the crippled Oroville Dam have made progress repairing the damaged spillway, state officials said.  //usat.ly/2lLPLzr   Join the Nation's Conversation To   A look around Oroville Dam as 200,000 people are evacuated None Rich Gray, of the Placer County Sheriff Dept., monitors the Oroville Dam's main spillway from a lookout point on Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Crews working around the clock atop the crippled Oroville Dam have made progress repairing the damaged spillway, state officials said. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP None Evacuees listen to an announcement lifting the evacuation of the Oroville Dam communities on Feb. 14, 2017, in Chico, Calif. Authorities lifted an evacuation order for thousands of California residents who live below the nation's tallest dam after declaring that the risk of catastrophic collapse of a damaged spillway had been significantly reduced. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP None A worker stands in the middle of the road, to monitor a road closure, atop the Oroville Dam on Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP None A Skycrane helicopter, left, returns to a staging area to be reloaded with rocks as another helicopter carries its load of rocks to fill in a hole on the Oroville Dam's emergency spillway on Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. The barrier, at the nation's tallest dam, is being repaired after authorities ordered mass evacuations for everyone living below the lake out of concerns the spillway could fail and send a 30-foot wall of water roaring downstream. Rich Pedroncelli, AP None Anthony Bradley, 12, center right, of Oroville, Calif., leaves a shelter with some balloons alongside his one-year-old niece Aunia Steele after a mandatory evacuation was lifted on Feb. 14, 2017, in Chico, Calif. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP Water gushes from the Oroville Dam's main spillway Tuesday, Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP None Play structures are submerged from the overflowing Feather River downstream from a damaged dam at Riverbend Park on Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP None Rylan Moua, left, and his uncle Christopher Vang, right, of Oroville, Calif., gather pillows as they leave a shelter after authorities lifted an evacuation order on Feb. 14, 2017, in Chico, Calif. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP None The Feather River flows with force through Oroville, Calif., downstream from a damaged dam on Feb. 14, 2017. Marcio Jose Sanchez, AP None Trucks line the Oroville Dam roadway as efforts to stabilize the emergency spillway continue on Feb. 14, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Michael Macor, San Francisco Chronicle, via AP None Crews work on a damaged section of the Oroville Dam in Oroville, Calif. on Feb.13, 2017. Josh Edelson, AFP/Getty Images None A home is seen marooned as the surrounding property is submerged in flood water in Oroville, Calif. on Feb. 13, 2017. Almost 200,000 people were under evacuation orders in northern California Monday after a threat of catastrophic failure at the United States' tallest dam. Officials said the threat had subsided for the moment as water levels at the Oroville Dam, 75 miles north of Sacramento, have eased. Josh Edelson, AFP/Getty Images None Helicopters transport large bags of rocks from the Oroville Dam parking lot to the eroded site at the Oroville Dam auxiliary spillway, in Butte County, Calif. Feb. 2017. California Department Of Water Resources, A look around Oroville Dam as 200,000 people are evacuated via European Pressphoto Agency None Oroville Lake, the emergency spillway, and the damaged main spillway, are seen from the air on Feb. 13, 2017 in Oroville, Calif. The erosion damage seen below the emergency spillway caused officials to issue evacuation orders yesterday to over 188,000 people in downstream areas. Elijah Nouvelage, Getty Images None A building is partially submerged in flowing water at Riverbend Park as the Oroville Dam releases water down the spillway as an emergency measure in Oroville, Calif., on February 13, 2017. Josh Edelson, AFP/Getty Images None Erosion caused when overflow water cascaded down the emergency spillway is seen, bottom, as water continues to flow down the main spillway, top, of the Oroville Dam on Feb. 13, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Rich Pedroncelli, AP None Luke Acosta, 14, and his dog, Skinny, slept in the back of his family's pickup truck at the Silver Dollar Fairgrounds on Feb. 13, 2017, in Chico, Calif., after residents were evacuated from the area due to fears of a possible failure of the emergency spillway at the Oroville Dam. Paul Kitagaki Jr., The Sacramento Bee, via AP None Water flows over the emergency spillway at Oroville Dam on Feb. 11, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. Water started flowing over the emergency spillway at the nation's tallest dam for the first time after erosion damaged the Northern California dam's main spillway. Rich Pedroncelli, AP None Lake water flows over the emergency spillway, bottom left, at Lake Oroville for the first time in the nearly 50-year history of the Oroville Dam on Feb. 11, 2017, in Oroville, Calif. The dam opened in 1968. Randy Pench, The Sacramento Bee, via AP None Paula Gillock, 53, waits in line for breakfast at the Silver Dollar Fairground on Feb. 13, 2017, in Chico, Calif. She left her home in Gridley and slept in her car with her cat Mimi after residents were evacuated from the possible failure of the emergency spillway at the Oroville Dam. Paul Kitagaki Jr., The Sacramento Bee, via AP None Water trickles down as workers inspect part of the Lake Oroville main spillway on Feb. 8, 2017 in Oroville, Calif. The California Department of Water Resources suspended the flow of water to inspect the damage to the main spillway. Randy Pench, The Sacramento Bee, via AP None Bags of rocks are seen in preparation for use in emergency measures at the Oroville Dam in Oroville, Calif., on Feb. 13, 2017. Almost 200,000 people were under evacuation orders in northern Calif. after a threat of catastrophic failure at the United States' tallest dam. Officials said the threat had subsided for the moment as water levels at the Oroville Dam, 75 miles north of San Francisco, have eased. But people were still being told to stay out of the area. Josh Edelson, AFP/Getty Images None This shows the water from the Oroville Dam Auxiliary Spillway at Lake Oroville as it continues to flow eroding the roadway just below the spillway that leads to the boat ramp in Butte County, Calif., on Feb. 12, 2017. Kelly M. Grow, AFP/Getty Images None A water utility worker peers over an eroded hillside as rushing water discharges down a spillway as an emergency measure at the Oroville Dam in Oroville, Calif., on Feb. 13, 2017. Josh Edelson, AFP/Getty Images None Jason and his wife Elizabeth Bourquin of Live Oak, Calif., settle in for the night with their son Dallas at the Neighborhood Church of Chico in Chico, Calif. Authorities ordered mandatory evacuations of communities below the Oroville Dam. Peter Dasilva, European Pressphoto Agency None Katherine Clark and Cal Poppen stay in the main sanctuary of the Neighborhood Church of Chico in California on Feb. 13, 2017. Peter Dasilva, European Pressphoto Agency None Alexis Nadercil-Gully looks in on Dillion the turtle, owned by Elizabeth Stone at the Neighborhood Church of Chico in California while they participate in a mandatory evacuation near the Oroville Dam. Peter Dasilva, European Pressphoto Agency None Porhue Yang, 8, watches a video at the Neighborhood Church of Chico in California while spending the night after authorities ordered mandatory evacuations of communities below the Oroville Dam. Peter Dasilva, European Pressphoto Agency None The Oroville Dam Auxiliary Spillway at Lake Oroville. California Department Of Water Resources via European Pressphoto Agency None An aerial view of the damaged Oroville spillway in Oroville, Calif. California Department Of Water Resources via European Pressphoto Agency None Chris Mitchell fills his car with gas as his daughter, Austin, checks her mobile phone before evacuating Oroville, Calif., on Feb. 12, 2017. Rich Pedroncelli, AP None California Highway Patrol officer Ken Weckman directs traffic as residents evacuate Marysville, Calif., on Feb. 12, 2017. Thousands of residents of Marysville and other Northern California communities were told to leave their homes as an emergency spillway of the Oroville Dam could fail at any time. Paul Kitagaki Jr., AP Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay
